data.title: Amazon readies plan to test its workers for COVID-19
data.text: Amazon.com Inc. AMZN, -0.01% said it plans to test front-line workers and eventually all of its workers for COVID-19.

data.title: Jeff Bezos makes surprise visit to Amazon warehouse and Whole Foods in NewYork
data.text: Amazon CEO wore a mask when showing up to meet employees at an Amazon warehouse and Whole Foods store after employees walked out and staged protests because of safety concerns during the coronavirus pandemic.

data.title: Amazon creating dedicated team of workers to begin testing its front-line workers for COVID-19
data.text: With thousands of its own workers on the front lines of the coronavirus pandemic as warehouse workers, delivery personnel, grocery workers and more, Amazon isn’t waiting around for testing to reach its necessary capacity.

data.title: Amazon says it could soon begin testing some warehouse workers for the coronavirus
data.text: Amazon has assembled a dedicated team to develop coronavirus tests that could later be deployed to workers.

data.title: The pandemic is playing to almost every one of Amazon's strengths
data.text: As the coronavirus pandemic has forced people to stay inside, few companies have proven themselves as essential as Amazon.

data.title: Another Sign of Surging Demand on Amazon.com
data.text: Amazon doesn't have enough capacity to offer its ancillary services profitably.

data.title: Jeff Bezos makes surprise visit to Amazon warehouse, Whole Foods
data.text: Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos visited one of his company's warehouses as well as a Whole Foods grocery store on Wednesday, making rare public appearances as employees have raised complaints about working conditions.

data.title: Why The Coronavirus Pandemic Could Be a Defining Moment For Amazon's Twitch
data.text: Did you catch the (video) game last night?

data.title: Jeff Bezos makes surprise visit to Amazon warehouse and Whole Foods store amid worker safety concerns
data.text: The visit comes as Amazon and Whole Foods employees have called for Bezos to better protect workers.

data.title: 3 Stocks to Buy & Hold for Decades
data.text: Each of these companies has a high probability of success over the next several decades.

data.title: 4 Cloud Computing Stocks to Beat Coronavirus Blues
data.text: To stay connected amid the coronavirus-induced lockdown, people across the world are relying heavily on the Internet, which brightens up prospects for cloud players.

data.title: Amazon is giving customers more time to return items during the COVID-19 pandemic
data.text: Amazon says that for its U.S. and Canadian customers, most items ordered between March 1, 2020, and April 30, 2020 can now be returned until May 31, 2020.

data.title: Why Amazon shipments are slow during this pandemic
data.text: Three reporters explain why the world's largest online retailer wasn't ready for this.
